Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Examining Early Stage Technology Firms' Use of Business Development Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Entrepreneurship is critical for job creation, economic growth, and innovation. Given the difficulty of starting and building new firms, public and private organizations have created venture development programs to help firms survive and succeed. The programs offer services, education and access to resources. Examples of venture development programs include government innovation grants, business incubators, private accelerators, university-based incubators, and venture capital. Billions of dollars are spent each year on and by venture development programs in the U.S. alone. Work has shown that these programs generally work; however, few studies have looked at the long term outcomes of these programs or the relative performance of the participating firms. This study develops a deeper understanding of nascent firm participation in venture development programs by determining how and why entrepreneurs use these programs, examining how development programs influence firm outcomes, and identifying the most useful elements of each type of program.

This research study has three parts. The first part builds a data set of nanotechnology firms in the U.S. by integrating several sources and includes detailed information about each firm, its participation in venture development programs, and the firms? outcomes. This part of the study provides insight into the types of firms that participate in the different programs. The next part of the study statistically examines how the participation in a program influences firm success. Multiple positive and negative firm outcomes are included such as business closure, bankruptcy, liquidation, acquisition, follow-on funding, and initial public offering to develop rich insights into these programs. The last part of this study asks firm founders about their participation in venture development programs and how their engagement of the programs influenced their firms? outcomes. Thus, this research expands our understanding of how technology firm founders can influence the longevity of their firms by participating in venture development programs. Understanding how entrepreneurs choose and engage these programs can improve the offerings from both the private and public sectors. Programs that influence the success of technology ventures are important for innovation, employment, and the federal funding of related education, research and development. Thus, this study supports policy makers in their endeavors to improve the development and availability of services and economic resources that support venture growth, innovation and national competitiveness.

Institution.Name: Santa Clara University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SANTA CLARA COLLEGE

POR.DRECONTENT:
RUI: Examining Nascent Technology Firm Use of Business Development Programs

Outcomes

 

Entrepreneurship is critical for job creation, economic growth, and innovation.  Given the difficulty of starting and building new firms, public and private organizations have created venture development programs to help firms survive and succeed by offering services, education and access to resources.  These programs include government innovation grants, business incubators, private accelerators, university-based incubators, and venture capital.  Billions of dollars are spent each year on and by venture development programs in the U. S. alone. 

While research has looked at the composition and impact of venture development programs individually, very little is known about how the participation in such programs differ or the relative influence of these programs on firm outcomes.  Furthermore, we currently lack a strong understanding of how venture development programs interact; an understanding acutely needed for improved entrepreneurial ecosystem efficacy. Thus this project develop a deeper understanding of nascent firm participation in venture development programs, build an empirical link between different development programs and firm outcomes, determine the mechanisms by which these programs are most effective, and explore the micro-processes of entrepreneurial action with regard to engaging external support.  The study looks at the use and influence of venture development programs with quantitative and qualitative methods. 

 

Intellectual Merit

This project crosses disciplines to compares multiple venture development programs and examines their interactions.  Further, multiple positive and negative firm outcomes will be examined such as business closure, bankruptcy, liquidation, acquisition, funding, and initial public offering to develop rich insights into these programs.  This study contributes to literatures on entrepreneurship, technology and innovation development, and science and innovation policy through two publications:

Woolley, J.L. 2019. "Gender, Education, and Occupation: How Founder Experiences Influence Firm Outcomes.” Academy of Management Discoveries, 5 (3), 266-290.

 

Woolley, J.L., McGregor, N. "Technology Start-Up Success at Private and University Business Incubators and Accelerators” which is under review.                   

These have been presented at the Academy of Management Conference and Atlanta Science and Innovation Policy Conference.

 

An additional manuscript working paper is near completion and will be submitted to an academic journal by the end of summer 2020.

 

Broader Impacts

In addition to conference presentations and journal articles, this project has funded eleven undergraduate research assistants from a variety of majors including management, computer science, and information systems.  All of these students have learned about nanotechnology and its applications in a wide range of businesses.  They also learned about entrepreneurship, incubators, invention commercialization, and firm founders. Overall, this project has greatly increased their appreciation for STEM entrepreneurship and innovation. 


Last Modified: 06/15/2020
Modified by: Jennifer Woolley
